This report identifies high-impact automation opportunities across all departments, from admissions to IT support, and where artificial intelligence (AI) can further accelerate efficiency.
foundations.full_excerpt:
Skilled nursing facilities (SNFs) face pervasive manual workflows and siloed systems that drain staff time and increase error rates. This report identifies high-impact automation opportunities across all departments, from admissions to IT support, and where artificial intelligence (AI) can further accelerate efficiency. Key findings include: (1) Top priority process automations (e.g. admissions, clinical documentation, staffing) that can eliminate re‐keying and redundant work, yielding up to 30–75% time savings and 25–50% error reduction in pilot cases[1][2]. (2) AI augmentations (e.g. NLP for document processing, LLM copilots for staff, predictive analytics for falls and readmissions) which, when applied to rich internal data, delivered measurable boosts like 40% faster information retrieval[3], 15–40% fewer adverse events[4][5], and 20% improvements in satisfaction[6] in early trials. (3) A cross-functional automation architecture emphasizing integration (APIs, HL7/FHIR), master data management, audit logs, and human-in-the-loop oversight to ensure scaling across 120+ centers securely and in compliance with U.S. healthcare regulations (e.g. HIPAA’s 6-year audit log retention[7]). (4) An open-first tooling landscape: we compare open-source options (workflow engines, RPA bots, OCR libraries, LLMs) with commercial vendors, noting that open solutions can often meet needs at lower cost – but commercial platforms may offer faster deployment or domain-specific features (especially for complex EHR integrations or sensitive AI uses, where 90% of nursing home leaders cite data security and regulatory support as top concerns[8][9]). The report ends with decision criteria for when to build vs. buy automation solutions. In short, SNFs have a vast automation opportunity to simplify and standardize processes that today burden staff and risk compliance. By first automating routine tasks (via integrations, RPA, OCR, etc.) and then layering AI judiciously (only where it demonstrably adds accuracy or insight), a multi-state operator can save thousands of staff hours, reduce errors by 30–85%, and improve care outcomes – all while navigating tight labor markets and stringent regulations[10][2]. The following sections detail these opportunities, including the “Top 25” automations to eliminate duplicate documentation and “Top 15” document-heavy workflows ripe for OCR in SNFs, with data-driven benchmarks and examples.
Modern SNFs remain encumbered by manual, paper-based workflows and double documentation across departments. This section explores automation opportunities for each core process area, focusing first on streamlining and integrating workflows (before introducing AI). For each function, we outline current-state pains, the tasks suited to automation, potential approaches (from API integration to RPA bots and OCR form processing), expected outcomes (time saved, error reduction, faster cycle times, etc.), and risks or failure modes to plan for. Federal requirements (HIPAA, CMS) and multi-state operations add extra complexity, but also make the ROI of automation especially compelling as it ensures consistency at scale. The tables under each sub-section summarize key metrics and benchmarks from industry case studies.
Current Pain Points: Admissions in SNFs are often time-sensitive but bogged down by manual data handling. Referral information arrives via fax or portal and must be re-keyed into facility systems; insurance eligibility checks are performed through separate payer websites; and bed assignment is managed on spreadsheets or whiteboards. These manual steps lead to delays in accepting referrals, errors in patient info, and suboptimal bed utilization. For example, delays in updating bed status occur in up to 30% of patient transfers, causing bottlenecks and longer wait times for incoming residents[11][12]. A manual bed board can also result in double-bookings or missed opportunities – one case study SNF had only 81% occupancy due to slow, paper-based bed tracking[13][14]. Intake coordinators spend hours duplicating demographics and payer info across forms, while families wait anxiously.
Automatable Units of Work: Key units include receiving a referral or hospital discharge packet (trigger), verifying insurance and Medicare/Medi-Cal eligibility, initial clinical screening for appropriate placement, checking current bed availability, obtaining prior authorizations if needed, and populating admission forms (face sheet, consent, advance directives, etc.). Outputs are an admitted resident record in the EHR, notifications to nursing and departments, and updated census/bed logs. Many of these steps are rules-based and repetitive – ideal for automation. For instance, a referral acceptance can trigger an API call or RPA bot to create a pending admission in the EHR and send templated welcome messages to the family.

Automatable Units: Key IT units: user provisioning/deprovisioning (triggered by HR events), access rights reviews (comparing user lists to current staff list, flagging discrepancies), helpdesk ticket triage (categorizing and routing tickets to the right tech or providing immediate solutions for known issues), password resets (can be self-service with multi-factor verification, or a bot that handles it), software patch deployment (scheduling and pushing updates to PCs after hours), report generation (automatically pulling data from systems and emailing to stakeholders on schedule). For facilities: work order generation (like if a temperature sensor triggers or time for monthly checks, auto-create tasks), preventive maintenance scheduling (calendarized PM tasks auto-assign to technicians and alert if overdue), asset tracking (scanning equipment barcodes and keeping logs automatically rather than clipboards). Also, safety/compliance checks can be scheduled and logged (fire safety drills, generator tests as mentioned – automate reminders and logging as part of maintenance system). Essentially, anything that’s a recurring support task or a trigger-based operational task can be automated – often through simple scripts or specialized management tools.
Automation Approaches:
- Identity & Access Management (IAM) Automation: Integrate HR systems with directory and application user management. For instance, when HR marks an employee as hired, an automation (via an IAM tool or custom script) can create their Active Directory account, set up email, add them to appropriate security groups, and even set up EHR access roles – all in seconds. Conversely, when someone leaves, automated deprovisioning revokes all accounts. According to an example from CloudEagle, companies spend ~500 hours a year on manual provisioning tasks that automation can virtually eliminate[135][136]. Automated provisioning also ensures no one falls through the cracks; this supports least-privilege principles (everyone gets only what they need from the start, as rules-defined)[127][137]. Also schedule regular access reviews: e.g. every quarter an automation emails department heads a list of their staff with system access to confirm – or more advanced, a tool can detect accounts inactive for 90 days and auto-disable (with a report to IT).
- IT Helpdesk Bots & Self-Service: Implement a self-service portal or chatbot for common IT requests. For example, a simple web form or chat where staff can reset their password after verifying identity (by code to their phone or answering security Qs), which triggers an automation to reset in AD/EHR immediately – no IT staff needed, cutting resolution from hours to seconds. MasterOfCode noted ROI in under 12 months for AI in healthcare support with such use cases (63% AI adoption in healthcare support in some surveys)[138]. Another is a knowledge base with automated answers: if a ticket comes in with keyword “printer issue,” an automation can send back a help article or walk the user through steps (and only escalate to human if that fails). A real NHS example showed saving 15 hours/week on average from RPA in admin tasks, with both hard and soft benefits[139].
- Monitoring and Alerting: Use IT monitoring tools with automated alerts – e.g. if a server’s disk space is low or a network goes down, an alert is automatically sent to on-call and perhaps an auto-remediation script runs (like clearing temp files). Similarly for facilities, IoT sensors (like temperature, humidity, fridge temps for med storage) can trigger alerts if out of range, avoiding manual daily logs and preventing incidents (this overlaps with EHR or compliance, but it’s operational automation).
- Report and Document Automation: Instead of IT pulling data for audits (user access logs, etc.), automate those reports. For instance, schedule a script to extract all logins from EHR monthly and highlight any anomalies (like logins after termination). Or auto-generate an equipment maintenance report for safety committee meetings. Tools like Power BI or even scheduled queries can do this, with results emailed out or put on dashboards. This ensures consistency and frees IT/analysts from repetitive report prep.
- Maintenance Management: Deploy a maintenance request app or system (even an easy email-to-ticket system) for staff to report issues. Automate assigning to the correct technician based on type/location. Integrate with inventory (so if a part is needed, the system can flag or order it). Schedule recurring maintenance tasks as work orders automatically. This reduces forgotten tasks – for example, a SNF chain might achieve near 100% on-time completion of monthly generator tests once it’s automated vs maybe 70% when relying on memory.
- Robotic Process Automation for Admin: For any miscellaneous administrative tasks – say compiling census numbers from each facility daily, or copying data between systems that lack integration – RPA bots can fill the gap. E.g. a bot could log into each facility’s EHR each midnight, pull census and compile a corporate census report by morning, replacing manual calls/emails. McKinsey research found healthcare has ~36% automation potential in operations like these[140][141].
Expected Outcomes: Automating IT and facility ops improves efficiency, reduces downtime, and strengthens security/compliance. For IT, user provisioning that used to take days (waiting for IT to create accounts) becomes instantaneous – new hires are productive Day 1. A case study at University of Kansas saw 66 hours annually saved just in provisioning time and another 48 hours in security review by automating user access workflows[142][142]. At scale, CloudEagle claims 500+ hours saved per year for onboarding tasks[135]. Those hours translate to either smaller IT staff requirements or more time for them to work on strategic projects rather than account admin. Self-service password reset dramatically cuts helpdesk tickets – some organizations have reduced IT ticket volume by 30–40% through these measures (for example, a study showed 37% of IT issues can be resolved via self-service with knowledge bases[143]). That means faster support for staff and less frustration; nurses aren’t stuck waiting to chart because of a locked account. For security, automated deprovisioning means zero orphan accounts lingering (compared to typical manual processes that often miss 10–15% of accounts after turnover). On compliance, regular automated access audits ensure least privilege is maintained, addressing a key HIPAA requirement[144][145]. Facilities maintenance automation ensures all required checks are done – possibly resulting in zero Life Safety citations on surveys, which is a big win. Also, quicker maintenance response improves environment of care (e.g. broken bed gets fixed sooner, improving resident safety). If IoT monitors free staff from manual logging (like fridge temps), that saves maybe 30 minutes a day for nurses and avoids incidents (like unnoticed vaccine fridge failures – which happened in some places with manual checks). Financially, efficiency gains in IT might not directly show on a balance sheet, but avoiding one serious security incident or survey citation can save tens of thousands. And by simplifying tasks, staff satisfaction goes up – IT staff can handle more facilities (scaling up without linear headcount growth) and nursing staff are happier with support (less waiting). Another quantifiable outcome: by automating repetitive admin tasks, some organizations achieve ROI in under a year on these tools[138].
Risks & Mitigations: In IT automation, a chief risk is that a script or bot could malfunction and cause bigger issues (like provisioning wrong access or deleting accounts incorrectly). Rigorous testing and starting with read-only or limited-scope scripts mitigates this. Also implement logging for all automated actions (so if a bot creates accounts, it logs that clearly – audit trails again). Coordination with HR is crucial – if HR data is wrong (someone labeled as terminated by mistake), an automated deprovision could cut off a real employee; hence include a human verification step in critical flows or at least quick rollback ability. For self-service, identity verification must be robust to avoid social engineering (one should enforce MFA or security Qs for resets to prevent unauthorized password resets). There’s a risk of relying on automation without oversight: e.g. an automated patch deployment might reboot a system at a bad time – schedule carefully and monitor. Ensure maintenance automation doesn’t replace physical walkthroughs entirely – you still need human eyes for some things. Also, technology adoption can be a challenge for maintenance staff if they’re not tech-savvy; pick user-friendly tools or provide training. Another risk is tool sprawl – adopting many different automation tools can itself be hard to manage; aim for integrated platforms where possible (maybe the same service desk can handle IT and facilities tickets for example). On the facility side, IoT sensors need to be maintained (calibrated, battery, etc.) – don’t set and forget, or you get false sense of security. Finally, if using open-source or custom scripts, ensure someone maintains them (if a key IT person leaves, you don’t want critical automations to break with no knowledge transfer – use proper documentation and backup plans). With proactive governance, the benefits of automating these support functions far outweigh the risks, leading to a more resilient and scalable operation.
IT & Ops Automation – Key Metrics:
The above metrics illustrate the range of improvements documented in case studies and industry benchmarks when SNFs automate processes across departments. In the next section, we explore how AI can further accelerate these gains, building on the automated foundations outlined here.
Basic automation streamlines workflows and removes inefficiencies; artificial intelligence (AI) can build on this foundation to handle unstructured data, provide decision support, and reveal insights that static rules cannot. This section examines key AI capabilities that can materially enhance skilled nursing operations beyond what integration and RPA alone achieve. We focus on AI use cases where there is clear value (e.g. interpreting free-text clinical data, predicting risk events) and emphasize open-source tools and architectures for each, noting where commercial solutions may be preferable. For each AI application, we discuss why AI (vs. just rules) is needed, data requirements and pitfalls, deployment considerations (on-prem vs. cloud, ensuring HIPAA compliance), open-source options vs. commercial vendors, and how to evaluate performance (accuracy, bias, safety). The AI categories addressed include: Natural Language Processing (NLP) for documents, speech recognition for clinical documentation, Large Language Model (LLM) “copilots” for staff, retrieval-augmented generation (RAG) over internal knowledge bases, predictive analytics for risk management, and computer vision/sensor tech for resident safety.

foundations.full_excerpt:
Automatable Units: Key steps include order transmission (e.g. sending lab orders or radiology requests directly from EHR to provider), results retrieval (getting lab results into the SNF record without someone scanning and uploading), referral initiation and follow-up (populating referral forms with existing data, automatically faxing or emailing them, and tracking status), and prior authorization workflows (submitting required data to payers for approval and checking status). Triggers could be a provider order entry or a care plan update that a consult is needed. Inputs are typically patient data, order details, and recipient info; outputs are confirmed appointments, completed orders, or authorization numbers. These steps can often be standardized (e.g. a referral packet always includes face sheet, recent labs, etc.), lending themselves to automation.
Automation Approaches:
- Integration with Provider Systems: Whenever possible, establish electronic interfaces with labs, pharmacies, and hospitals. For labs, use HL7 orders (ORM messages) from the SNF EHR to the lab system, and HL7 results (ORU) back – eliminating phoned orders and scanning results. Many SNFs already interface with pharmacy systems for eMAR; extending that to other orders is feasible with modern EHRs or middleware (like an HIE or interface engine).
- Electronic Referral Management: Implement a referral management tool or use direct messaging (Direct Secure Email) to send structured referrals to specialists or home health agencies. Tools can auto-attach required documents and even suggest preferred network providers. This speeds up response times – some SNFs report referral review times dropping by 80% with digital workflows[43].
- RPA for Web Portals: If a payer requires using a web portal for prior auth, an RPA robot can input resident data, upload documentation, and periodically check for determination, instead of staff constantly rechecking. Similarly, bots can log into hospital discharge portals to fetch new referrals or into state Medicaid systems to pull needed auth forms. Sparkco notes that robotic process automation can gather and verify multi-payer data “in minutes rather than hours,” drastically cutting utilization review time[44][45].
- Workflow Automation & Alerts: Use workflow engines to coordinate multi-party handoffs – e.g. when a referral is sent, automatically set a task to confirm appointment scheduled within X days, and alert if not done. Automate notifications: family and internal stakeholders get templated updates when an outside appointment is set or results come in (reducing phone tag).
- Rules Engines for Decisions: Employ rules or simple AI to triage which referrals or orders need extra steps. For example, a decision table can route a STAT lab order differently (immediate call-out) vs routine. Or in prior auth: a rules engine could auto-approve common requests that meet criteria and flag only the tricky ones for manual review, accelerating throughput[46][47].
Expected Outcomes: Streamlining orders and referrals speeds up care and reduces administrative overhead. In utilization management, AI and automation have shown up to 80% reduction in review times – tasks that took 5 days manually can be done in 1 day[48]. One study estimated automating prior authorizations and clinical reviews could cut administrative costs by 50–70%, potentially saving $13.3 billion annually in healthcare[49][50]. SNFs that automated referral intake have seen huge efficiency gains: for instance, an AI referral platform helped some facilities review referrals 90% faster and make decisions in minutes instead of hours[51][17]. By automating data exchange, care transitions are smoother – labs results arriving 65% faster during audits in one example[52]. Fewer handoffs means fewer errors: automating prior auth data entry can reduce human errors by 90% (no more typos in auth requests)[53][54]. Compliance and throughput improve too: case studies show 25% faster approval turnaround on automated prior auths[55], meaning patients get needed treatments sooner. Another benefit is reduced denials: by catching missing info and standardizing submissions, SNFs using automated denial management saw denial rates drop by 30–40%[56][57]. Overall, better coordination automation leads to more timely care (e.g. timely specialist visits can reduce acute transfers) and financial gains (fewer missed billing due to lost orders or lack of auth).
Risks & Mitigations: The main risks are integration errors or mismatches – e.g. an automated order might go out with the wrong patient identifier or a bot might select a wrong menu item on a payer site. To mitigate, thorough testing with each partner system is needed, and maintain a human oversight especially early on. Communication with external partners is key: not all doctor offices or vendors are ready to receive automated communications, so a fallback (like generating an email or notifying staff to call if electronic fails) ensures continuity. Another risk is workflow exceptions: e.g. an urgent order that doesn’t follow normal pattern – staff must be trained to handle those outside the automation. Monitoring is crucial; for instance, if an RPA fails to get a prior auth response, an alert should flag staff rather than the referral being forgotten. It’s also important that automating referrals remains resident-centric: ensure no referral gets sent without appropriate clinical review – some steps might intentionally remain manual (like a nurse’s approval) with automation handling the grunt work around it. Finally, keep audit logs of all automated communications (who sent what, when) to satisfy any regulatory scrutiny about coordination of care. With these safeguards, automating orders/referrals can significantly improve the speed and reliability of SNF care coordination.
Orders & Care Coordination Automation – Key Metrics:
Current Pain Points: Staffing and HR processes in nursing homes involve significant manual coordination and paperwork. Staff scheduling often relies on a scheduler’s spreadsheet or even paper sign-up sheets, leading to last-minute scramble to fill open shifts when call-outs occur. Without automation, identifying who’s available for an extra shift requires multiple phone calls or texts. This manual approach contributes to excessive overtime and use of expensive agency staff. In fact, many senior care providers report built-in overtime due to suboptimal schedules – one vendor notes up to 70% reduction in overtime after implementing scheduling software[60]. Call-out handling is another pain: when a nurse calls out at 5 AM, manually waking up and contacting replacements can delay coverage, risking care ratios. On the HR side, onboarding new hires requires assembling packets of forms (I-9, W-4, direct deposit, policy acknowledgments) and tracking that all documents are signed – often via physical paperwork that HR must chase and file. This is time-consuming and prone to errors (missing signatures, etc.). Credentialing and training compliance adds further manual burden: keeping track of dozens of nurses’ license renewals, in-service training, TB tests, etc., usually via spreadsheets or tickler files. Missing a deadline can lead to non-compliance (e.g. an aide with an expired certification on the floor during a state survey is a serious issue). Additionally, timekeeping and payroll in many SNFs involve manual data transfer – time clock data might be printed and keyed into a payroll system, introducing errors and delays (and disputes about hours). All these duplicative workflows sap administrative time and can result in costly mistakes (like overpaying due to time entry errors or fines for lapsed certifications).
Automatable Units: In scheduling: posting open shifts, matching staff availability, and sending out shift requests are prime for automation. The unit “open shift needs assignment” can trigger a cascade of automated texts to eligible staff, first-come-first-serve filling, and automatic roster updates. In HR onboarding: once a candidate is hired, generating all required forms and collecting e-signatures can be automated, as well as provisioning system accounts (tie-in with IT). Time and attendance units like clock-in/out can be integrated with scheduling to flag overtime in real time. Tracking credentials is an ideal automatable unit – e.g. monitoring license expiration dates in a database and auto-emailing staff and managers 60 days prior. Payroll processing units include capturing time clock data and performing calculations (PTO, overtime) then exporting to accounting – these can be rule-driven and scheduled. Essentially any repetitive HR data process (benefit enrollment entry, performance review reminders, etc.) can be automated to some degree.

- Scheduling Software & Integration: Adopt a scheduling platform (many are cloud-based) that automates shift assignments and staff communication. Advanced scheduling systems use algorithms to optimize schedules, ensuring fair distribution of shifts and minimal overtime. They can automatically enforce rules (e.g. required RN per shift, or no more than 16-hour shift lengths). Mobile apps or SMS integration let staff receive and accept open shift invites instantly, which has been shown to raise fill rates dramatically (some SNFs achieve 95%+ fill rates with such tools, versus 80–85% manually)[61]. Integration with time clocks ensures schedule adherence is tracked.
- Call-Out & Overtime Alerts: Use workflow automation to handle call-outs – e.g. an employee texting “CALL OUT” to a certain number triggers a bot to mark them absent and broadcast the open shift to a pre-defined list of qualified staff. The system can escalate (e.g. if unfilled after 15 minutes, widen the pool or alert a manager). Also set up overtime alerts: if a staffer is about to hit overtime, the system can notify the scheduler or automatically seek alternatives for the next shift. These measures cut unintended overtime – for instance, OnShift (a scheduling vendor) cites clients seeing 26% reduction in OT costs after automation[62].
- Digital Onboarding & HR Workflow: Implement an HR workflow tool or an onboarding portal for new hires. This allows all forms to be filled electronically with e-signatures (no printing). Data from a single input populates all necessary systems: for example, the new hire’s info flows into the payroll system, the scheduling system, and the HRIS, eliminating duplicate data entry (a common theme – up to 50% of HR data may be redundantly entered across systems without integration[63][64]). Use RPA if needed to bridge legacy HR systems that lack APIs – e.g. an RPA bot can take new hire data from a central form and input it into a 20-year-old HR database UI.
- Credential Tracking Automation: Maintain a centralized credential database and use automated reminders (via email/SMS) to notify staff and HR of upcoming expirations (licenses, CPR certifications, training). Even better, integrate with licensing boards’ systems (some states have public APIs or data for license verification) so the system can automatically verify renewals. Some open-source tools or simple scripts can regularly check a nurse license against the state database and flag any that become invalid.
- Payroll and Timesheet Automation: Integrate time clocks (or use modern digital clock apps) with payroll. An automation can perform 2-way matching: compare schedule vs actual clock times to flag discrepancies (reducing fraud or errors) – some SNFs achieved a 50% drop in payroll discrepancies by integrating scheduling and payroll data[65]. RPA can also assist by extracting timesheet reports and importing into payroll software if direct integration isn’t available. Additionally, use rules to automatically apply payroll policies (e.g. auto-add shift differentials or deduct meal breaks) to minimize manual adjustments.
Expected Outcomes: Automating workforce management yields significant labor cost savings and improves compliance. Scheduling automation can massively reduce overtime and agency usage: facilities using OnShift reported 26% lower overtime costs and 20% less agency reliance[62]. Faster response to open shifts means fewer gaps – one system achieved 96% shift fill rate (up from 82%) and filled shifts 30% faster than before[66]. A case example showed overtime hours dropped 38% (saving ~$8,000 per month for a mid-size facility) after implementing an optimized scheduling tool[67]. Administrative time spent scheduling can drop by 70% (e.g. a scheduler going from 20 hours a week creating schedules to 6 hours)[68]. On the HR side, moving to digital onboarding and credential tracking eliminates mountains of paperwork – HR teams can process onboarding 50% faster and ensure 100% completion of required forms, whereas previously things slipped through cracks (e.g. missing I-9s). Automated reminders drastically cut credential lapses; organizations have reported reducing compliance violations related to staffing by 40% once automated tracking and alerts were in place[69]. Payroll accuracy improves with integration – one study found automated time/pay systems cut payroll processing time by 30% and reduced errors nearly 100% (95%+ fewer manual mistakes)[70][71]. Furthermore, staff retention can improve: easier scheduling and less clerical drudgery correlates with increased staff satisfaction. Case studies note a 15–20% decrease in staff turnover after implementing employee-friendly scheduling apps, as staff felt more control and predictability[72]. In sum, automation in staffing and HR can save significant money (by trimming overtime and agency spend), ensure regulatory compliance (no expired licenses or missing trainings), and boost workforce morale.
Risks & Mitigations: A potential risk is staff mistrust or misuse of automation. For scheduling tools, if not implemented with transparency and input, staff might find them impersonal or confusing – mitigating this with training and having “super-users” on each unit to assist is important. Data integrity is crucial: incorrectly configured rules (e.g. wrong overtime rule) could shortchange staff pay or overschedule someone – rigorous testing and parallel runs of new systems vs old are needed initially. Also, ensure labor law compliance in automated scheduling (the system must respect state regs like maximum hours, required breaks, etc.; built-in rules or checks handle this). For HR data, privacy and security of personal info must be maintained – use secure, HIPAA-compliant platforms for any PII in onboarding. There’s also a change management factor: long-time schedulers might resist handing over control to an algorithm, or HR staff might be wary of RPA. Emphasize that automation assists rather than replaces their expertise, and redirect their roles to higher-level oversight (e.g. focusing on recruitment and employee engagement rather than data entry). When integrating systems, a risk is synchronization issues – mitigation is to have one “source of truth” (for instance, HRIS as master for employee data) and ensure others subscribe to updates properly. Lastly, always have a contingency: if the scheduling system goes down, maintain a procedure to manually contact staff (perhaps keep an export of staff contacts). With these considerations, SNFs can confidently modernize workforce management, turning chaotic scheduling and HR fire-fighting into a streamlined, proactive operation.
Workforce & HR Automation – Key Metrics:
Current Pain Points: SNF finance departments handle high volumes of repetitive transactions – vendor invoices, purchase orders (POs), expense reports, etc. Accounts payable (AP) is particularly labor-intensive if done manually: invoices arrive via mail/email, an AP clerk must key each into an accounting system, match it to POs or delivery receipts, obtain manager approvals, and finally cut checks. In healthcare, over 80% of organizations still rely on manual AP processes, leading to delays and errors[75]. The cost to process a single invoice manually can be $10–$15 (including labor)[76], versus a few dollars with automation. Without automation, invoices might sit in inboxes, causing late payments – indeed, 40% of AP teams cite slow invoice validation as a cause of late payments[77][78], which can incur fees or lost early-pay discounts. Additionally, duplicate payments or errors (like paying the same invoice twice, or coding it to wrong department) are risks; manual AP processes typically have around a 2% error rate annually, which automation can cut to ~0.8%[71]. Purchasing and inventory ties into AP: without an integrated system, there’s duplicate entry from requisition to PO to invoice. Other finance tasks like 2-way/3-way matching (reconciling invoices to POs and receiving) and vendor onboarding (collecting W-9s, insurance certs) are often done via email and spreadsheets, burdening staff and delaying procurement. All these manual finance workflows increase overhead – administrative expenses can be 15–25% of healthcare costs[79], and simplifying these can directly improve margins.
Automatable Units: Key units include invoice capture (reading invoice data into the system), matching and approval routing (comparing invoice to PO and routing to manager for approval if within thresholds), payment processing (generating ACH/check with proper coding), and vendor data management (keeping track of vendor compliance docs, avoiding duplicate vendor entries). Also, expense report processing for staff (which can be automated with receipt OCR and policy rules) and bank reconciliation tasks are candidates. Essentially, any repetitive finance data process with defined rules can be automated: e.g. “if invoice amount within PO tolerance, auto-approve; if > $X, route to regional director.” Many SNFs use standardized G/L codes – applying those by rule (based on vendor or item) can save manual coding effort. Vendor onboarding units (collect W-9, verify against IRS TIN matching) can be partially automated through integrations with IRS databases and secure form portals.
